content: Hi y'all. The lang team was looking at rfcs#2000 and issue #44580 . We saw that @lcnr posted an amazing comment , which gave us some idea of status.
the lang team was then wondering: should issue #44580 be closed, since rfcs#2000 seems mostly implemented, and new tracking issues filed for any new work?

and we were also wondering what you all thought would be best way for track ongoing design and implementation work. We know there's a lot of energy being spent in this space, a lot of excitement, and we want to figure out a way to bubble that energy, at least some of it, out to the Rust community at large.
the RFC seems to specify that N + 1 should work
(it does not currently and is a long way off)

so maybe the question becomes: assuming making N+1 work is desireable (and it sounds desireable to me), what is the plan for getting there? what is the path, and what are the intermediate milestones we can use to tell if we're going the right way?

(I don't expect an immediate/short answer to that. Its more a big picture question. The fact that the lang team's synopsis was to ask "can we close this?" is a sign that we don't have a good view of what the goal is and how far we are from it.)
don't have the time to think about the best reply today, but currently the path forward is still not that clear. my gut reaction is that keeping #44580 is useful
feel free to ping me in a few days if i don't reply by then

pnkfelix said:

so maybe the question becomes: assuming making N+1 work is desireable (and it sounds desireable to me), what is the plan for getting there? what is the path, and what are the intermediate milestones we can use to tell if we're going the right way?

are these questions you would actually like answered or is this rhetorical :sweat_smile:
I won't get upset if they don't get answered
it was as much an internal reflection on "what would make life easier for me right now as a member of the lang team" (apart from infinite spare time and domain knowledge).

should issue #44580 be closed, since rfcs#2000 seems mostly implemented, and new tracking issues filed for any new work?

It's only used for progress updates, these could be "inside rust" blog posts instead. So it probably doesn't make too much sense as a tracking issue. Think closing it and then linking from each blogpost to the previous one is better.

what you all thought would be best way for track ongoing design and implementation work.

Currently it's very hard to parallelize and generally unclear how to go forward here. Slowly getting around to thinking that we should actually just write a book in the project-const-generics repo to track and explore future work and possibilities. Going to try starting that today.

what is the plan for getting there? what is the path, and what are the intermediate milestones we can use to tell if we're going the right way?

The plan is vague, the path is foggy and most intermediate milestones are still partially burried in the sand. Should write a book :sparkles: we then have a collections of necessary steps and additions which should be far easier to track.
adt_const_params currently still points at #44580 as its tracking issue, going to change that and then close #44580 as long as @project-const-generics doesn't have any concerns here
